sect1.title: Impact of Sex/Gender, Culture, Race, Age, and Other Aspects of Diversity
sect1.para: This section emphasizes the the importance of incorporating identity as a contextual factor when considering personality disorder diagnoses. Specifically, this section will present evidence on the impact of several identities, including age, culture, race and ethnicity, sex, gender and gender expression, and sexual orientation on the manifestation of personality disorder symptoms or maladaptive traits and functioning. This section concludes by highlighting the importance of awareness of bias that can result in wrongly pathologizing identities.

sect2.title: Age
sect2.para:
Age is a contextual factor factor impacting PD diagnosis due to the heterogeneous presentation of symptoms in younger and older populations as a result of generational differences, cognitive changes, and physical changes. DSM states that the age of onset for PDs is during adolescence or early adulthood (American Psychiatric Association, 2013 ). Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) Antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) is the only PD that overtly requires the occurrence of symptoms in adolescence. This diagnostic criterion may make it more more difficult to diagnose the disorder in older adults due to cognitive decline that may prevent some older individuals from providing a detailed account of behavioral patterns in their adolescence or young adulthood that will meet ASPD diagnostic criteria (Holzer & Vaughn, 2017 ) and may contribute to the difference in diagnostic prevalence in younger and older populations. Individuals with ASPD may engage in more risky behaviors, leading to incarceration or death, contributing to further differences in diagnostic prevalence throughout the lifespan (Holzer & Vaughn, 2017 ). Finally, existing DSM diagnostic criteria for ASPD ASPD
include include engaging in behaviors that require substantial energy including physically aggressive behaviors toward others and criminal behaviors. When conducting diagnostic assessments for ASPD, it is important to consider the heterogeneous presentation of aggressive behavior that does not only include physical assaults or criminal behaviors that warrant arrests because physical strength and engagement in criminal behaviors have been shown to decrease with age (Holzer & Vaughn, 2017 ). Other Other expressions of aggression can include non-violent behaviors such as verbal aggression, purposefully damaging others’ personal properties, intentionally spreading rumors about others, or harassing them indirectly through other means.

More recently, some researchers researchers have questioned whether PDs can emerge in older adults. Because the age of onset for DSM-5-TR personality disorders is during adolescence/early adulthood, the onset of personality disorders in older adults is not well-researched. Stone et al. ( 2023 ) argue traumatic experiences are strongly associated with personality dysfunction or psychological diagnosis in older adults. In a study that examined the late onset of personality disorders in individuals older than 55, the researchers found the occurrence of a personal illness illness and illness or death of a relative predicted the onset of personality disorders (Dupree et al., 2023 ). Dupree et al. ( 2023 ) attributed the occurrence of late onset of personality disorders to a change in the individuals’ roles in life from from being “healthy” to “unhealthy” or independent to dependent. This could be an important consideration when conducting diagnostic interviewing of personality disorders in older populations. More generally, due to the unique context of later life, researchers have proposed “geriatric variants” for all of the DSM-based PDs (Segal et al., 2006 ), which could be used to help clinicians and researchers researchers identify (and study) unique presentations of PDs in later life.

sect2.title: Culture
sect2.para: When making a clinical clinical diagnosis of a PD, it is important to consider cultural differences and how these might impact the presentation of symptoms. The consideration of cultural practices is important in working with individuals from diverse backgrounds because the clinician must consider whether symptom expressions are typical of cultural expressions or a deviance from it. Cultural context can provide a more comprehensive understanding of an individual’s symptoms especially as it relates to PD diagnosis because it concerns how a person’s culture is impacting how they think, express how they feel, and react to certain events events . Additionally, one’s cultural expression of feelings and emotions is especially important because some translated versions of Western instruments, especially diagnostic interviews, may not convey the same meaning. For example, some have argued that diagnostic criteria, such as fear of abandonment, are not appropriate in collectivist cultures. Some cultural expressions that may be considered pathological pathological may be common practice in one’s culture, and this could lead to misdiagnosis. For example, in some Indigenous communities, an appropriate expression of grief includes hearing the voices of dead ancestors (Balaratnasingam & Janca, 2017 ).

In a study that examined the heterogeneous cultural representations of self-harming behaviors behaviors and the psychological stressors of borderline personality disorder (BPD) borderline personality disorder (BPD) , individuals from Eastern cultures (e. g., East Asia, East India, Morocco, Hong Kong, India, and Japan) were more likely to engage in self-harming methods self-harming methods such as self-poisoning and overdose (Munson et al., 2022 ). This This may be due to discouragement of externally expressing one’s emotions in Eastern nations. Additionally, these methods may be used because poisons and chemicals are more commonly accessible in the regions where the the studies were conducted. In Western nations (e. g., Canada, Croatia, Italy, Norway, Sweden, the United States, and Western Australia), it was found that skin mutilation was more common. This may be because individuals from Western nations are more emotionally expressive (Munson et al., 2022 ). It is not possible or expected of any clinician to be knowledgeable of all people’s cultural backgrounds. However, one’s culture should be considered in diagnostic interviewing of personality disorders to gather more information about the context in which the symptoms may occur. If the clinician is not well-educated well-educated on the individual’s cultural background, it is encouraged that the clinician does the necessary research into the individual’s cultural practices and expressions. It is also important for clinicians to not assume that a patient fully identifies within a specific cultural background, thus clinicians should consider assessing how each each patient identifies with a cultural background. Finally, one’s culture may be informative of the differential stressors such as political and social climates that may impact the onset onset of PDs (Munson et al., 2022 ).

sect2.title: Race and Ethnicity
sect2.para: When working with individuals individuals from diverse, underrepresented, and epistemically excluded populations, clinicians should be aware of personal biases. These biases can impact the type of diagnosis a patient may receive. When conceptualizing a diagnostic assessment, clinicians should be aware of the possible biases that may contribute to their decision of a diagnosis. For example, racial stereotypes associated with certain groups should be of note to prevent bias in diagnostic interviewing and conceptualization. Previous research suggested PDs were more frequently diagnosed in racial and ethnic minoritized groups compared to to their White counterparts (e. g., Grant et al., 2008 ; Huang et al., 2006 ; Tomko et al., 2014 ).

However, more recent research research has found that some racial and ethnic groups may have lower prevalence rates of personality disorders than White populations. In a meta-analysis that examined how race and ethnicity impacted the prevalence of PDs, individuals who identified as Black had a lower rate of diagnosis of a personality disorder than individuals who identified as White (Mc Gilloway et al., 2010 ). When comparing rates of PD diagnoses of individuals who identified as Asian and White, there were no statistically significant differences. Although there were also no statistically significant differences in individuals who identified as Hispanic and White in their PD diagnoses, Hispanic populations Hispanic populations were found found to be more likely to be diagnosed with a PD. The authors concluded that while the significantly lower diagnoses of PDs in Black populations could be a true lower prevalence rate, this also could could be due to potential neglect of assessing PD diagnoses in ethnic groups (Mc Gilloway et al., 2010 ). In another more recent study that examined PDs across racial groups from hospital admissions data across 6 years, they found that Black and other minority ethnic groups had lower prevalence rates of PDs than the White British population (Hossain et al., 2018 ). Whether racially and ethnically minority groups are over or underrepresented in PD diagnosis, it is important to be aware of potential diagnostic biases against racial and ethnic groups. It is important for the assessing clinician to be aware of their own biases biases and beliefs about stereotypes they may have toward certain groups.

sect2.title: Sex and Gender Identity and Gender Expression
sect2.para: Another important important identity aspect to consider in diagnostic interviews of PDs is sex and gender differences. An individual’s gender identity may impact the diagnosis they receive due to potential biases that some clinicians have toward gender identities. Alternatively, a person’s sex and gender identity can impact how symptoms present due to the association of certain behaviors with different gender identities. For For example, a cisgender woman with borderline personality disorder (BPD) borderline personality disorder (BPD) may display more overt mood fluctuation, fear of abandonment, and interpersonal difficulties due to societal associations and expectations of femininity while a cisgender man with BPD may feel pressured to suppress their emotional oscillations and express it through overtly aggressive behaviors or risk-taking behaviors to align more with societal expectations of masculinity. Research shows differential behavioral correlates in men and women diagnosed with BPD (Sher et al., 2019 ) where where men with BPD scored higher on aggression and impulsivity measures than women. Similarly, the manifestation of symptoms of antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) differs by the binary expression of gender (Sher et al., 2015 ). In individuals diagnosed with ASPD, women were found to have committed less antisocial acts than men. Additionally, boys later diagnosed with ASPD may have an earlier onset of conduct disorder and are more likely to engage in aggressive acts than adolescent girls. Dimensional Dimensional models of PD may decrease gender biases. For example, when a case vignette was described in terms of Five-Factor Model components, there were no sex differences in the ratings as compared compared to the DSM ratings (Samuel & Widiger, 2009 ).

sect2.title: Sexual Orientation
sect2.para: Another factor factor in diagnostic interviewing of PDs that can be impacted by bias is sexual orientation. In a study that examined bias in the diagnosis of BPD in sexual minority individuals, compared with their heterosexual counterparts, sexual minority individuals were more likely to receive a diagnosis of BPD (Rodriguez-Seijas et al., 2021 ). The authors noted that individuals in this sample who were diagnosed with BPD also had other comorbid psychopathologies and maladaptive personalities. However, even after controlling for these clinical correlates, the diagnostic disparity between sexual sexual minority individuals and heterosexual individuals in BPD still persisted, providing providing evidence for diagnostic criteria bias against sexual minority individuals. Rodriguez-Seijas et al. ( 2021 ) also investigated diagnostic disparity in diagnostic instruments in this group. Results were stratified based on sexual orientation subgroups including heterosexual, lesbian/gay, and bisexual individuals. The disparity in diagnostic methods among sexual orientation subgroups was greatest among bisexual individuals. Rodriguez-Seijas et al. ( 2021 ) suggested future research focus on investigating potential reasons that may have led to this disparity including diagnostic instrument differences or clinician’s unfamiliarity with how personality pathology symptoms symptoms manifest in non-heterosexual populations.
